newsitem.title: CANADA: Canadian bonds end stronger but underperform U.S..
newsitem.headline: Canadian bonds end stronger but underperform U.S..

text.p: Canadian bonds closed stronger in thin trade on Friday, pulled higher by gains in U.S. Treasuries, but underperforming the U.S. market amid weakness in the Canadian dollar, analysts said.

"We're still being weighed on a little bit by this weakness in the currency. I think that's caused some level of underperformance," said Jim Webber, director of fixed income research with TD Securities Inc.
Canada's 30-year benchmark bond rose C$0.56 to C$116.18 to yield 6.688 percent against the U.S. 30-year bonds, which rose 31/32 to yield 6.36 percent.
The spread between the benchmark bonds widened to 33 basis points from 29 basis points at Thursday's close.
The Canadian dollar weakened sharply on Friday, closing at C$1.3513 (US$0.7401) from Thursday's close at C$1.3463 (US$0.7428) after disappointing third-quarter current account numbers.
Statistics Canada this morning reported the country's current account surplus came in at a lower than expected C$551 million in the third quarter.
The weakness in the dollar and the disappointing report led Canadian bonds to underperform, Webber said.
Dealings were thin in the Canadian market after the U.S. Thanksgiving holiday on Thursday, traders said.
In other prices, the Government of Canada's 7.0 percent of 2006 rose C$0.51 to C$107.40 to yield 6.004 percent. The U.S. 10-year bond rose 18/32 to yield 6.05 percent.
The negative spread between the two narrowed to five basis points from six basis points at Thursday's close.
Canada's three-month cash bill traded at 2.74 percent against the U.S. bill at 5.13 percent.
